circa 1875-1950
PR 42Collection processed by N-YHS staff New-York Historical SocietyNew-York Historical Society170 Central Park WestNew York, NY 10024 (212) 873-3400This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2020-02-10T21:39:14English
New-York Historical Society
McKim, Mead and White Architectural Record Collection PR 42
286 Linear feet (677 boxes, 13 drawers), plus 15 shelves of bound volumes and 3,046 rolls of architectural drawings
circa 1875-1950 Department of Prints, Photographs and Architectural Collections. The McKim, Mead and White Architectural Collections consists of architectural drawings, correspondence, photographs, scrapbooks, financial records, and specifications documenting individual projects of the firm as well as its overall operations.
Scope and Contents
The McKim, Mead and White Architectural Record Collection spans the period from ca. 1875 to 1950 and includes the major portion of the firm's records. The collection consists of more than 61,000 architectural drawings, including ink on linen, blueprints, and other media; 1,500 photographs, including prints and glass and film negatives; 700 boxes of correspondence and specifications; 54 ledgers, including 17 bill books (1878-1947), 10 cash books (1894-1944), 8 contract books (1903-1930), and 9 journals (1882-1942); 30 photo albums and scrapbooks; and more than 300 original line drawings made to illustrate A Monograph of the Works of McKim, Mead and White, 1879-1915 (all numbers are approximate). The material contains extensive documentation of the firm's operations and of individual buildings, although most information about the firm's early years can be found in the photograph albums, clippings scrapbooks, and financial ledgers.
Included in the collection are Shingle Style, Colonial Revival, and other country houses in Newport, Rhode Island; urban residences such as the Villard Houses, New York; public commissions including Boston Public Library, Rhode Island State Capitol, and Prospect Park entrances, Brooklyn, New York; and universities, museums and libraries including the restoration of the University of Virginia rotunda, Columbia University and Pierpont Morgan Library, New York.
The collection is organized by the following formats: architectural drawings, correspondence, specifications, photographs, scrapbooks and photograph albums, newspaper and journal clippings, financial records, and publications.
More detailed finding aids for portions of the collection are available on-site. Researchers wishing to access the collection must schedule an appointment in advance. Requests for appointments and other questions should be submitted to the librarian for the Department of Prints, Photographs and Architectural Collections at printroom@nyhistory.org.
Use restrictions
Permission to reproduce any Print Room holdings through publication must be obtained from:
Rights and Reproductions
The New-York Historical Society

New York, NY 10024
Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282
Fax: (212) 579-8794

The copyright law of the United States governs the making of photocopies and protects unpublished materials as well as published materials. Unpublished materials created before January 1, 1978 cannot be quoted in publication without permission of the copyright holder.
Grateful Acknowledgment
The drawings in the McKim, Mead and White collection were re-housed and inventoried with the help of a 2009 grant from the federal Save America's Treasures program.
Provenance
Gift of the firm, 1950 and 1968.
Access Restrictions
Open to qualified researchers by appointment. Appointments must be scheduled in advance by contacting the Department of Prints, Photographs and Architectural Collections at printroom@nyhistory.org.
Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.)
Biographical / Historical
Charles McKim (1847–1909), William Rutherford Mead (1846–1928), and Stanford White (1853–1906) established their partnership in New York City in 1879 and soon became the premier architectural firm in the United States. Between 1879 and 1912, the firm received nearly 1000 commissions, designing a wide array of residential, institutional, commercial, and public buildings in New York and other cities. Influenced by their extensive travels (and training) in Europe, the firm designed primarily in the Beaux Arts style, becoming the leading proponents of a return to classicism as an expression of American architectural character. The firm's work at the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago in 1893, featuring the "White City," also helped to launch the "City Beautiful" movement.
Among the firm's many notable buildings are Pennsylvania Station (1910, razed 1963), the Morgan Library and Museum (1903, expanded 1928), the Brooklyn Museum (1895), and the Municipal Building (1909-1915).
While associated primarily with the Gilded Age, the firm continued for more than three decades after the death of the last founding partner (Mead) in 1928, and trained many significant 20th century architects, including John Carrere and Thomas Hastings.
Arrangement
The collection is currently organized by format into the following eight series:
Series I: Architectural drawings
Series II: Correspondence
Series III: Specifications
Series IV: Photographs
Series V: Scrapbooks and photograph albums
Series VI: Newspaper and journal clippings
Series VII: Financial records books
Series VIII: Publications
Related Collections at the New-York Historical Society
The personal papers of Stanford White are held by the Library's Department of Manuscripts.
Preferred Citation
This collection should be cited as: McKim, Mead and White Architectural Record Collection, PR 42, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.
Related Materials at Other Institutions
Additional McKim, Mead and White drawings and photographs are held by Columbia University's Avery Architectural and Fine Arts Library.
Charles Follen McKim's papers are held by the Library of Congress' manuscript division. Series I: Architectural Drawings53033
Conditions Governing Use
Researchers wishing to access architectural drawings should be aware that due to their fragility and volume, special handling procedures apply to these materials. Accordingly, researchers should consult with the Print Room Librarian about how much time to budget when scheduling an appointment to view architectural drawings.
The majority of drawings are stored on rolls; unrolling and rerolling these drawings is a time consuming process, so only a limited number of rolls can be viewed per visit. Multiple visits will be required for researchers wishing to view a significant number of drawings.
To preserve drawings for future research, the following restrictions apply:
1. All research appointments must be scheduled in advance through the Print Room Librarian.
2. Researchers will be required to wash their hands at the institution prior to handling archival materials.
3. Librarians will page only one tube or folder of architectural drawings at a time. No additional materials will be paged until all previously accessed drawings have been re-rolled and/or re-housed.
4. No drawings will be paged after 2:00 PM (or within one hour of closing time).
5. The Librarian has the discretion to limit the number of rolls a researcher may view per visit.
6. Damaged or particularly fragile drawings may, in the Librarian's discretion, be handled only under the direct supervision of a librarian or withheld pending review by the chief conservator.Subseries I.1: Rolled drawings53278
Scope and Contents
Included in this series are approximately 61,150 rolled drawings for over 1000 commissioned projects. Approximately 65 percent of these are tracings (mostly ink on linen), and 35 percent are print duplicates (mostly blueprints on paper). They consist of plans, elevations, sections, exterior and interior details, full size details, sketches, and shop drawings. Projects include educational institutions, banks, country estates, residences, clubs and casinos, hotels, memorials, government buildings, public buildings, commercial buildings, libraries, museums, churches, and hospitals in New York and elsewhere.
The drawings were re-housed between 2009-2012 pursuant to a generous Save America's Treasures grant from the National Park Service, in partnership with the National Endowment for the Arts, the National Endowment for the Humanities, the Institute of Library and Museum Services, and the President's Committee on the Arts and Humanities.
This subseries includes drawings of many of the firm's most important projects in New York City and elsewhere. An item-level inventory of the rolled drawings is available on-site.Subseries I.2: Flat drawings53040

Scope and Contents
This series consists of approximately 665 hollinger boxes of documents -- primarily letters, but also a large amount of billing correspondence and some contracts. The files also occasionally include small drawings, rough sketches, specifications, photographs and clippings. A small amount of additional correspondence may be located in Series III, Specifications.
The documents in this series are arranged by project. A box list is available on-site.Series III: Specifications53253
Scope and Contents
This series includes approximately 63 boxes of specifications, arranged by project. Esquire Residence73271III.627Whitney, W.C., Long Island73272III.631Whitney W.C., City House, NY73273III.632Willard, Joseph E., NY73274III.633Willard, Joseph E., Richmond, VA73275III.634Women's Golf and Tennis Club, Glen Head, LI73276III.6358th East 56th Street, NY73277III.636Series IV: Photographs53035Subseries IV.1: Photographic prints53042
Scope and Contents
This subseries is comprised of 68 boxes, primarily of photographs, but also including copy photos of architectural drawings, printed material (offprints from publications, entire publications, postcards), newspaper clippings, documents from Departments of Documents and Buildings (generally for New York City projects), handwritten notes, and sometimes correspondence or blueprints.
Most of the photographs are site photographs, showing exteriors and interiors, made either prior to, during, or after construction (but generally undated). Photographers included are Blackman Photo Service, Edwin J. Cardswell, Louis H. Dreyer, Gottscho-Schleisner, H. Ernest King, Schuyler Carteret Lee, J.C. Maugans, C. Ording, Richard Averill Smith, Adolph Studly, Tebbs Architectural Photos, Irving Underhill, United States Army Signal Corps, DeWitt Ward, and Wurts Bros.
The photographs are housed by size (small, medium and large), and within each size category are arranged alphabetically by project. A box and folder list is available on-site.Sub-subseries IV.1.A: Small photographs53556
Note
Small photographs are arranged by project. A box and folder list is available on-site.Projects A-Z536081-42Sub-subseries IV.1.B: Medium photographs53557
Note
Medium photographs are arranged by project. A box and folder list is available on-site.Projects A-Z5360943-65Sub-subseries IV.1.C: Large photographs53558Unidentified interior5357066Harvard Club, exterior5357166Pennsylvania Station, photograph of a drawing 5357266Pennsylvania Station, photograph of a plan5357366Pennsylvania Station, interior, photograph of a drawing5357466Louis Sherry, 2 exteriors5357566Lawrence Grant White House, 277 Park Avenue, 3 exteriors5357666Hall of Languages, NYU, exterior5357766Columbia University, aerial view5357866Goelet Office Building, 2 exteriors 5357966Colony Club, exterior5358066Brooklyn Elks Lodge, exterior?5358166Tiffany Building, exterior5358266University Club, exterior5358366Group Portrait of Office5358466Low Library, Alma Mater5358566Interborough Power House 5358666Franklin National Bank 5358766New York Athletic Club, exterior5358866New York Life Building, exterior5358966Sherry Building, exterior5359066Goelet Building, exterior5359166Russel Erwin Building, exterior5359266Joseph Pulitzer House, exterior5359366Gibson House, exterior5359466Freundschaft Society, exterior5359566Municipal Building, 5 views of the exterior5359666King Apartment House, 139th St., 2 views of the exterior5359766H.A.C. Morgan, Newport, RI, drawing5363668Unidentified college buildings5363768Harvard University Graduate School of Business Administration, Boston, MA, plan5363868Section, theatre for Amherst College, Amherst, MA5363968Amherst College, Amherst, MA, mounted photograph (very poor condition. Broken in two pieces)5364068Subseries IV.2: Glass negatives53252
Scope and Contents
This subseries includes approximately 600 8 by 10 inch glass negatives.Series V: Scrapbooks and photograph albums53043
Scope and Contents
This series includes 30 blank-paged leather-bound volumes with photographs, maps, sketches, and/or floor plans pasted in. Some of the albums have been disbound and re-housed in folders due to their deteriorating condition. Most albums depict MMW projects and are devoted to either a particular project or a general category of work. There are also a few albums of non-MMW work which probably served as sourcebooks for the firm's architects to draw ideas from.
Detailed inventories for some of the scrapbooks are available on-site.Photograph scrapbook, New York University534661898SB-1
Scope and Contents
Scrapbook contains maps, sketches, and photographs of building exteriors, fields, barns, dormitories, the library, Havemeyer Chemical Laboratory, staircases, general construction, and the Hall of Languages in University Heights. 1898.Clippings scrapbook (mainly non-MM&W Beaux-Arts competitions)53471undatedSB-2
Scope and Contents
This album does not appear to contain the work of MM&W. Instead, the majority of photographs and sketches concern themselves with various Beaux-Arts Architects and competitions. There are several decorative elements at the beginning of the book.Scrapbook of MM&W Commissions, 1870-1888534731870-1888SB-3.1
Existence and Location of Copies
The original is restricted due to condition issues. A photocopied version (Volume SB-3.2) is available for researchers.
Scope and Contents
Comprehensive collection of plans, photographs, designs and articles relating to McKim, Mead and White commissions. There are several unidentified buildings. Articles pertain to the building, construction, and controversy (such as the trustees of the Boston Public Library choosing McKim, Mead and White over the Boston city architect).Scrapbook of MM&W Commissions, 1870-1888 (facsimile)535591870-1888SB-3.2Record Work534701888-1906SB-4.1
Scope and Contents
Disbound scrapbook of MM&W works-in-progress.
Folder 1 includes images of ceiling details, doors under construction, columns waiting to be installed, and crude sculptures. The only dated photograph is from 1894, for the Power House in Niagara Falls, NY. Majority of pictures are unlabeled.
Folder 2 includes interiors, tombstones, cemeteries, unidentified houses, Shinnecock Hills, the Ascension Church, and sculptures of lions and children.
Folder 3 includes an urn, the construction of Staatsburgh, Ophir Farm, the rotunda at the University of Virginia, 110 Bleecker Street, Joseph's Pulitzer's door, a storehouse, sculptures, and unidentified buildings. Several photographs include workmen and pedestrians.
Folder 4 includes the Chandler, Whitney, and Williams houses under construction, along with the unveiling of the Peter Cooper Memorial. Scenes from what appear to be the World's Fair, and decorative elements belonging to unidentified residences also appear in the folder.
Folder 5 includes the George Williams house, the Vanderbilt residence, the Duseen (?) building, and a mausoleum. Several sites and buildings are unidentifiable.
Folder 6 includes Ferncliff Casino, the Hecker Mausoleum site, the Twombley plot, the Philadelphia Art Museum, Whitelaw Reid residence, and the Paulist Fathers Church.
Folder 7 includes Beacon Rock, the Pierpont Morgan Library, Harvard Gates, and the Knickerbocker Trust Company. There are multiple street scenes that include the Hotel Manhattan, Grand Central Station, the Astor, and the Old Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Folder 8 includes the Ochre Point home of Robert Goelet, and at least two non-MM&W projects: the improvement of Copley Square, and a Roman School. There are also several unidentified houses and churches.
Folder 9 includes projects that were not designed by MM&W, including the Roman School, Mr. Treat Campbell at 298 Broadway, Fort Greene Park, Holt Monument, and what appears to be a triumphal arch. There are also several photographs highlighting construction workers, cows, landscapes, and a man standing between a column and a lightpost. Record Work535481833-1909SB-4.2
Scope and Contents
The majority of designs are by the firm of McKim, Mead and White. Other architects are J.H. Duncan, Seth Greer, and U.H. Mullins. There are photographs of proposed sites, additions, interiors, and even an analysis of capitals. Grant's Tomb, by J.H. Duncan, is also included.Scrapbook of architectural details53484SB-5.1
Scope and Contents
Original drawings of architectural details such as columns and archesScrapbook of architectural details53485SB-5.2
Scope and Contents
Original drawings of architectural details such as columns and archesPhoto Album A-Z (folders 1-6)534601901-1914SB-6.1
Scope and Contents
Folder 1 includes what appear to be mausoleums, and decorative elements for the exterior.
Folder 2 includes exterior photographs of residences and buildings, several photographs show the stages of construction. Some pictures are closeups of entryways. Also shows crowds of men outside the New York Herald, and the statue being placedon top of the building.
Folder 3 includes buildings in various states of construction and finish, and exterior renovations. There are also street scenes, and several pastoral scenes in photographs. One interesting photograph in folder 3 features only a man in a field of cows.
Folder 4 includes exteriors and interiors of buildings, along with street scenes. Photographs show construction, workers, pedestrians, and several photographs are of architectural models for the Girard Trust Company. Clubs, a high school, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art also feature. Photo Album A-Z (folders 7-11)53486undatedSB-6.2
Scope and Contents
Folder 9 includes photographs the floor test in the Amherst Laboratory, and the coffered ceiling detail of Winnipeg Bank.Early work of firm53487SB-7New York State College of Agriculture (Cornelius White, architect)53488SB-7Schools and Colleges53274SB-8Sculptures and Monuments53275 1889-1912SB-9
Scope and Contents
Majority of work in album not done by McKim, Mead and White. This appears to be a scrapbook of ideas, inspiration, and competition in the fields of architecture and sculpture.
One object of note in Folder 2 is a painting of Lady Charles Spencer. Folders 3 and 4 focus on expositions and exhibitions at the end of the 19th and beginning of the 20th century, including the Pan-American Exposition, Buffalo, NY; Louisiana Purchase Exposition, St. Louis, MO; Trans-Mississippi Exhibition, Omaha, NE; World's Columbia Exposition, Chicago, IL; and the Exposition of 1900, Paris, France. Architects are noted whenever possible.Parks, monuments and landscape gardening53468SB-10Modern sculpture53489SB-11
Scope and Contents
Consists of photographs of non-MM&W sculpture. Most pages are blank.Office Work53465SB-12
Scope and Contents
Mostly exterior photographs of residences, the RI state capital building, a statue, and New York office buildings.Country work532761879-1912SB-13.1
Scope and Contents
Disbound photo album of commissioned McKim, Mead and White residences, buildings, gazebos and clubs. Interior photographs are included. Highlights include Box Hill, Stanford White's residence in St. James (Folder 1); the Orange Y.M.C.A. building (Folder 2); and a spectacular bird's eye view of Naugatuck, CT (Folder 7). Also features work commissioned by Edwin Dennison Morgan, John Jacob Astor IV, C.H. Mackay, George G. King, University of Virginia, L.C. Hanna, the Sherry Casino, and Dr. R.H. Derby.Country work53549SB-13.2
Scope and Contents
Bound album of commissioned McKim, Mead and White residence, buildings, gazebos and clubs.Foreign work (folders 1-6)532771902-1910SB-14.1
Scope and Contents
None of the work represented in the album was designed by McKim, Mead and White. This most probably served as an architectural sourcebook for the architects to draw ideas from. Photographs show architectural details, interiors, facades, tombs, monuments, and other sculptural and architectural elements. Also includes copies of floor plans for many palaces and residences.Foreign work (folders 7-14)535501902-1910SB-14.2Iron work534921897-1902SB-15
Scope and Contents
Architectural scrapbook of ideas for the firm of McKim, Mead and White. Iron-work dominates the folder. Many photographs are from the Museo Nazionale in Naples, Italy. There is one double-helix staircase that bears a strong resemblance to the double-helix staircase at Rosecliff, a mansion the firm designed and built between 1897-1902.Houses - Twombley, Nickerson and others53469SB-16
Scope and Contents
Includes work commissioned by Hamilton McKay Twombly, owner of Florham Farms in Madison, NJ, and a residence for George A. Nickerson, in Boston, MA. Also included is another unidentified residence.Walker O. Cain & Associates, Book of photographs by Mr. Mead532731883-1907 SB-17
Scope and Contents
Subject matter includes buildings, plans, decorative elements, and elevations from apartment houses to the Payne Whitney House (includes many unidentified projects). There are also photographs of construction sites, alleyways, streets, and parks.Girard Trust53261SB-18Bellevue Hospital53262SB-19Bank of Montreal53263SB-20.1Bank of Montreal53551SB-20.2Report of the Washington Park Commission53271SB-21Henry B. Hollins Townhouse53555SB-22Stanford White residence - St. James53264SB-23Stanford White residence - 121 East 21st Street53265SB-24.1Stanford White residence - 121 East 21st Street53552SB-24.2Stanford White residence - 121 East 21st Street53649SB-24.3Clarence MacKay residence (Harbor Hill)53266SB-25Hoving residence (?)53267SB-26H.W. Poor residence53554SB-27Boston Public Library53268SB-28University of Virginia53269 1895-1898SB-29
Scope and Contents
Photographs of the construction and completion of the Rotunda, buildings in the South Lawn Complex, and Rouss Hall are featured in the album. Also included are interior photographs, and several shots of arcades.Columbia University (folders 1-6)532701895-1897SB-30.1
Scope and Contents
Several photographs show construction workers.
Photographs in the first 5 folders focus on the construction of the Columbia College Library. A few photographs from the completed building show students using the Reading Room. Folders 5 and 6 show construction on the University Building. Columbia University (folders 7-12)53569SB-30.2
Scope and Contents
Folder 7 shows the construction of and completed Physics Building. Folders 8 and 9 focus on the Natural Science Building. There are other photographs in folder 9 of the Engineering Building. The Chemistry Building is shown in folders 9 and 10. Folder 12 has a few photos of Hamilton Hall.Series VI: Newspaper and journal clippings53477
Scope and Contents
This series consists primarily of newspaper and magazine clippings concerning McKim, Mead and White projects; also included are special reprints of clippings and of published photographs. The clippings were originally pasted in volumes which have been disbound due to their deteriorating condition.Clippings 1889-1901534781889-1901C-1

Scope and Contents
Includes journal clippings, pictures from journals, drawings and plans. Subjects includes statutes, monuments, residences, banks, memorials, clubs, university buildings, and a laboratory for the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens.

Scope and Contents
This series includes 54 volumes of financial records books, divided into the following seven categories: bill books, cash books, journal books, ledger books, contract books, and miscellaneous financial records books. The bill books include typed carbon copies of accounts; the remaining books consist primarily of handwritten financial account ledgers.
For additional copies of bills and statements, see Series II, Correspondence.Subseries V.1: Bill Books53254Bill book July 1878 - March 188453493FR-1Bill book April 1884-May 188753494FR-2Bill book May book53547FR-54Series VIII: Publications53279
Scope and Contents
This subseries includes two boxes of what appear to be proof plates for A Monograph of the Works of McKim, Mead and White, 1879-1915, published in phases from 1915 to 1920, as well as the plates for McKim, Mead and White houses and casinos featured in George William Sheldon's Artistic Country-Seats, published in 1886.
Also included is the firm's copy of the 1899 Sanborn fire insurance Atlas of New York City.
The Print Room also holds a complete set of the original plates for A Monograph of the Works of McKim, Mead and White, 1879-1915. The call number for the set is Print Room Rare NA737.MR A5 1915.Plate proofs, A Monograph of the Works of McKim, Mead and White, 1879-1915, Volume 1.53280P-1Plate proofs, A Monograph of the Works of McKim, Mead and White, 1879-1915, Volume 2.53560P-2Plates for MMW houses and casinos featured in George William Sheldon's Artistic Country-Seats, 1886.53561P-3Sanborn Atlas of New York City, Volume 1: Battery-14th Street535621899P-4Sanborn Atlas of New York City, Volume 2: 14th-59th Street535631899P-5Sanborn Atlas of New York City, Volume 3: 59th-110th Street535641899P-6Sanborn Atlas of New York City, Volume 4: 110th-145th Street535651899P-7Sanborn Atlas of New York City, Volume 5: 145th Street-Spuyten Duyvil535661905P-7
